description:
Helps implement some missing scaling modes to get rid of artifacts and jitters on low res games:
- KeepScaling = 1:1 Letterbox with upscaling
- PixelScaling = 1:1 Letterbox without upscaling
- IntegerScaling = Integer Letterbox with upscaling

You should only use one of these in your project.
Incomplete with a few things still needing to be done manually. 
You will probably need to thoroughly test and put in extra work on the extension if you are planning on using it in production.
name: IntegerScaling
shortDescription: Helps implement some missing scaling modes.

eventsFunctions.description:
Implements dynamic integer scaling for your game resolution to prevent tearing and other artifacts for pixel games.
Works for both portrait and landscape mode. 

This also avoids scaling to where game elements are not inside of the display window as the default resize modes do, and margins are displayed instead.

LIMITATIONS:
- This only works on the base layer - Use the "CopyCameraSettings" extension to apply this for any additional camera layers.

NOTES: 
- Target resolution width and height is the resolution that will be internally rendered until the game window is resized, at which point the resolution will also be proprotionally dynamically resized.
- Note that camera zoom level is NOT dynamically changed, which means the layout viewing bounds will be different depending on the window size.
          - use the 'KeepScaling' event if you want the game to look exactly the same regardless of window size
          - the limitation there is that it will be scaled by whole integers only, leaving a lot of blank space depending on window size and project resolution

- You can make the target resolution a multiple of your project properties and camera zoom to keep the width and height aesthetic you setup in project properties. For example:
     Project properties W x H = 320 x 160
     Zoom level = 3
     Target W x H = 320*5 x 160*5 = 960x480

- Zoom level and target resolution don't have to be at a multiple of the project properties resolution, feel free to play around and find what looks best for you.
eventsFunctions.name: IntegerScaling
eventsFunctions.sentence: Configure resolution of _PARAM1_ x _PARAM2_ , with Zoom of _PARAM3_, and set window size to _PARAM4_ x _PARAM5_ - center window: _PARAM6_

parameters.description: Target resolution Width you'd like your game to run at
parameters.name: TargetResW

parameters.description: Target resolution Height you'd like your game to run at
parameters.name: TargetResH

parameters.description: How much to zoom the camera after re-scaling to the target resolution
parameters.name: ZoomLevel

parameters.description: Whether to center the game window on the screen
parameters.name: CenterWindow

eventsFunctions.description:
Implements 1:1 integer scaling for your game resolution to prevent tearing and other artifacts for pixel games.
Works for both portrait and landscape mode. 

This also avoids scaling to where game elements are not inside of the display window as the default resize modes do, and margins are displayed instead.

LIMITATIONS:
- This only works on the base layer - Use the "CopyCameraSettings" extension to apply this for any additional camera layers.
- Because we are keeping 1:1 ratio here you CANNOT go below what you put in as TargetResW and TargetResH - those are your minimum game resolutions.


NOTES: 
- Target resolution width and height is the resolution that will be internally rendered until the game window is resized, at which point the resolution will also be dynamically resized but keep the 1:1 pixel ratio.
- Note that layout viewing bounds will be different depending on the window size.
          - use the 'PixelScaling' event if you want 1:1 scaling without upscaling the base resolution
          - the limitation there is that things may get jittery at low resolutions and pixel snapping is recommended

- You can make the target resolution a multiple of your project properties and camera zoom to keep the width and height aesthetic you setup in project properties. For example:
     Project properties W x H = 320 x 160
     Zoom level = 3
     Target W x H = 320*5 x 160*5 = 960x480

- Zoom level and target resolution don't have to be at a multiple of the project properties resolution, feel free to play around and find what looks best for you.

eventsFunctions.sentence: Keep resolution of _PARAM1_ x _PARAM2_ , with Zoom of _PARAM3_, and set window size to _PARAM4_ x _PARAM5_ - center window: _PARAM6_

parameters.name: TargetResW

parameters.description: Target resolution Height you'd like your game to run at

eventsFunctions.description:
Implements 1:1 integer scaling for your game resolution to prevent tearing and other artifacts for pixel games.
Works for both portrait and landscape mode.

No upscaling is done so pixel snapping is highly recommended. You will have jitters with Camera movement if you don't do your own pixel rounding on it.
Provides an 'old-school' pixel game aesthetic.

This also avoids scaling to where game elements are not inside of the display window as the default resize modes do, and margins are displayed instead.


NOTES: 
- Target resolution width and height is the resolution that will be internally rendered until the game window is resized, at which point the game will also be resized, keeping the 1:1 pixel ratio and not performing any upscaling.
          - use the 'KeepScaling' or 'IntegerScaling' events if you want to upscale the base resolution when the window is resized

- Set the target resolution to what you would normally setup in project properties.
eventsFunctions.name: PixelScaling
eventsFunctions.sentence: Keep resolution of _PARAM1_ x _PARAM2_ , and set window size to _PARAM3_ x _PARAM4_ - center window: _PARAM5_

parameters.description: Target resolution Width you'd like your game to run at
parameters.name: TargetResW

parameters.description: Target resolution Height you'd like your game to run at
parameters.name: TargetResH

parameters.description: Whether to center the game window on the screen
parameters.name: CenterWindow
